entry.title: Variable Pay - Guidelines showing decimal places
entry.content:
Hi Variable Pay experts!

I need help with removing the decimals from the guideline column (column ID totalIndividualGuideline) in our Variable Pay worksheet as they are currently showing with 2 decimal places e.g. 70.00% - 100.00% instead of 70% to 100%. The money format against this column is custPercentFormat (#,##0.0000) and I have tried changing this to all other options in the dropdown list but the decimals remain. This is particularly odd and last year's template has the same column with the same format and the decimals do not show there. 

Any ideas?? Thank you!

Hi @Brinda911,

Thanks for the additional information.

For using the Sales BOM process (Sales Kit sales process in public cloud), the pre-reqisite is to active the Scope item 31Q in CBC.
Then create the BOM with useage 5 and use it in OR document type.

Surya.

entry.title: Efficient Pagination in SAP CPI Using OData Services
entry.content:
Introduction

When working with large datasets in SAP Cloud Integration (CPI), pulling everything at once from an OData service can cause serious performance issues â€” think timeouts, memory overload, and slow processing. Thatâ€™s where pagination comes in. Instead of fetching all the data in one go, you break it down into smaller, manageable chunks. This approach keeps your integration flow efficient and reliable.

In this guide, weâ€™ll walk through a practical example using the Northwind sample OData service to show how pagination can make your life easier.

Step 1: Start with a Timer

Kick things off with a Timer-based trigger in your integration flow. Why? Because it lets you schedule the process to run automatically â€” perfect for recurring tasks like syncing data every day or every hour. No manual intervention needed; just set it and forget it.

Step 2: Add a Looping Process Call

Next, youâ€™ll need a way to fetch data in chunks until everything is retrieved. Thatâ€™s where the Looping Process Call comes in. It repeatedly calls the process to get the next page of data.

Hereâ€™s what to configure:

  • Condition Expression:
    ${property.Receiver1.OData.hasMoreRecords} = 'true'
    This tells the loop to keep running as long as there are more records to fetch.

  • Max Iterations:
    Set this to 10 (or tweak it based on how much data you expect). This acts as a safety net so the loop doesnâ€™t run forever.

  • Action When Limit Reached:
    Choose Throw Exception. This ensures you have control if something goes wrong â€” the loop stops instead of endlessly spinning.

Step 3: Modular Local Integration Process 

Within each loop iteration, invoke a Local Integration Process. This modular approach keeps your main flow clean and separates pagination logic for better maintainability.

Step 4: Configure the Request-Reply Adapter

Inside your Local Process, set up the Request-Reply Adapter to talk to the OData service. This is where you define how the data will be fetched.

Hereâ€™s what you need to do:

  • Adapter Type:
    Choose OData V2 â€” itâ€™s the standard for most SAP scenarios.

  • Authentication:
    For this demo, set it to None. (In real projects, youâ€™ll want proper authentication for security.)

  • Resource Path:
    Use Customers â€” this tells the adapter which dataset to pull.

  • Query Options:
    Add $select=CustomerID,Address,City to fetch only the fields you need. This keeps the payload light and efficient.

  • Page Size:
    Set it to 3. This means youâ€™ll get three records per request instead of everything at once.

  • Process in Pages:
    Enable this option. Itâ€™s the magic switch that makes pagination work.

This setup ensures youâ€™re pulling data in small, controlled batches â€” reducing system load and improving overall performance.

Step 5: Content Modifier for Data Aggregation ğŸ—‚

After each page fetch:

  • Use a Content Modifier to store the current payload.
  • Aggregate the results across iterations for further processing or output generation.

This step is crucial for building a complete dataset from paged responses.

Integration Flow at a Glance

Your flow will look something like this:

Timer
â†’ Looping Process Call (handles pagination logic)
â†’ Local Process Call (fetches each page)
â†’ Request-Reply Adapter (OData V2 interaction)
â†’ Content Modifier (aggregates results)

Key Things to Keep in Mind

  • The property
    ${property.Receiver.OData.hasMoreRecords} = 'true'
    acts as a flag to tell the loop whether more pages are available.

  • You can add a Filter Step to pull only the data you actually need from each page â€” this keeps things clean and efficient.

  • Use the Content Modifier for aggregation. This ensures large datasets are handled in a controlled way without overwhelming your system.

entry.title: Enterprise Generative AI and Governance in SAP
entry.content:
Artificial Intelligence isnâ€™t something futuristic anymore itâ€™s already here, designing how businesses work every day. SAP has been quick to adopt this change by adding Generative AI features through tools like SAP AI Core, SAP AI Launchpad, and the SAP Generative AI Hub.

These tools help companies use AI securely and responsibly. But as AI becomes more powerful, it also needs proper governance to make sure data stays safe, results are reliable, and everything is used in an ethical way.

In this post, letâ€™s explore how SAP combines the power of Generative AI with smart governance to help businesses innovate confidently.

What is Generative AI in SAP?

Generative AI in SAP simply means using advanced models (like large language models) that can understand and generate content whether thatâ€™s text, insights, or suggestions based on real business data.

You will find it in action in places like:

  • Chatbots for customer support
  • Automatic report generation
  • Predictive maintenance
  • Employee self-service portals

SAP enables all this through AI Core and AI Launchpad, which connect these models to real systems such as S/4HANA, MDG, or SAP Datasphere.

The Big Picture: SAPâ€™s Enterprise AI Architecture

If we zoom out, the Generative AI setup in SAP can be viewed in three layers:

  1. Data Layer â€“ This is where all the clean, governed, and reliable business data lives.
  2. AI Layer â€“ The acts as brain that processes and manages AI models.
  3. Application Layer â€“ The part users actually see apps, dashboards, or assistants that use AI insights.
  1. AI Model Lifecycle in SAP

AI models are not one-and-done projects. They need to be developed, deployed, monitored, and improved over time.

In SAP setup the process usually looks like this:

 

  1. Develop â€“ Train or fine-tune a model using relevant business data.
  2. Deploy â€“ Move it into production through SAP AI Core.
  3. Monitor â€“ Keep an eye on accuracy, performance, and compliance.
  4. Update â€“ Refresh or retrain the model as new data or business needs emerge.

This continuous cycle make sure that AI models stay useful, accurate, and secure. 

Why Governance Matters

Governance is what keeps AI on the right track. SAP focuses on three main principles here .

It ensures that:

  • Only clean and approved data is used for training.
  • Model outputs can be explained and audited.
  • Legal and ethical standards are always met.

Think of governance as the safety net that allows businesses to innovate with confidence instead of risk.

A Real Example: AI-Powered Sales Assistant

Imagine you are a part of a sales team using an AI assistant inside SAP Fiori.

You type a customerâ€™s name and within seconds it gives you key details, suggests pricing, and even drafts a response email for it.

Hereâ€™s what is happening behind the scenes:

  • MDG provides clean and accurate customer data.
  • AI Core processes your request with Generative AI.
  • The AI assistant presents it in a clear, user-friendly interface.
  • Every step is logged for security and compliance.

The result?

There is less manual work, faster decisions, and more time to focus on actual selling.

My Final Conclusion:

Generative AI in SAP is transforming how businesses run making systems smarter, faster, and more intuitive.

But innovation alone isnâ€™t enough. To really make AI work for the long run, companies need to have solid data governance and a clear AI lifecycle in place.

When these two go together, AI stops being just a tech it becomes a true business advantage.                                 

                                                                                                                                                 Published by

                                                                                                                                                  Nikhat Fatima

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC): A Beginner's Guide - Part 1
entry.content:
Introduction

Let's understand what is SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC). SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) is a unified data platform which means a single environment that harmonizes information from all SAP and non-SAP sources into a trusted semantic layer. BDC can be the organization's single source of truth which provides a consistent, governed layer of data that everyone can use, whether itâ€™s for analytics, planning, or building AI Applications. 

 

But the bigger topic is why do we even need something like SAP Business Data Cloud?

Why do we need Business Data Cloud? 

Today every organization is talking about being â€˜data-driven.â€™ We all want to make decisions based on real insights rather than gut feeling.  But in reality, its not that easy. the truth is data is everywhere. But it's rarely in one place or in one consistent format. Businesses have information scattered across multiple systems . Like some in SAP applications like S/4HANA or SuccessFactors, some in non-SAP platforms, spreadsheets, or even external sources like partners and IoT devices. So when companies try to bring that data together for analytics or AI, they face a few very real challenges.

  1.  How do you build a single, complete data foundation that supports modern AI and machine learning models?
  2.  How do you trust your data? how do you ensure quality, consistency, and integrity so that the decisions you make are actually reliable?
  3.  How do you extract real business value from this massive, mixed pool of structured and unstructured data?

SAP recognized that these are the exact pain points stopping companies from truly using data to their advantage. And thatâ€™s what led to the creation of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC).

One of the major innovations behind BDC is how it eliminates data fragmentation. Instead of moving data between systems and losing context along the way, BDC integrates data in real time while preserving its business meaning. For example, if the same business entity, say a customer exists in multiple SAP systems, BDC brings together under a unified definition using the One Domain Model. So business users don't have to worry about where the data came from or how it's structured. They simply work with consistent, harmonized business entities that are ready for analytics, reporting, or Artificial Intelligence (AI). 

The best part is SAP fully manages the entire lifecycle. BDC is delivered as a Software-as-a-Service solution built on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).  Because of that all the integration, replication, and governance are handled by SAP. In the past, customers had to manually extract and prepare SAP data before it was usable for analytics. That process was slow, expensive, and error-prone. With BDC, thatâ€™s all automated so organizations can focus their time and resources on building innovative AI models, automating insights, or improving business performance instead of just wrangling data.

Let's take a practical scenario, imagine a large enterprise with data coming from ERP, HR, procurement, and expense systems. Traditionally, every system had its own data units, and teams had to spend weeks just preparing the data before running any kind of analysis. Now, with SAP Business Data Cloud, all of that data whether itâ€™s from SAP S/4HANA, SuccessFactors, Ariba, Concur, or even non-SAP systems can be harmonized and made available in one place instantly. That gives the business a 360-degree view across operations, employees, customers, and suppliers. The platform supports a wide range of use cases from data warehousing and BI, to AI and machine learning, planning, governance, and even intelligent application development. Basically, itâ€™s an end-to-end solution that connects data and intelligence across the entire organization. The real value, however, is in the trust and governance that come built-in. Because BDC leverages SAPâ€™s domain expertise and semantic understanding of business data, it ensures that what you see in your reports and AI models actually reflects reality not inconsistent or duplicate information.

So to sum it up, SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) transforms how organizations manage and use their data. It addresses the three biggest challenges of the data-driven world:

  1.  Building a single, reliable foundation for AI and analytics
  2.  Ensuring data trust and quality
  3.  Unlocking the full value of structured and unstructured data across the enterprise

It's like a bridge that connects all the data sources, both internal and external into one governed, business-ready environment. In other words, it takes us from data chaos to clarity. It helps organizations move beyond just having data, to truly using it to drive growth, innovation, and intelligent decision-making.

Key Components of SAP Business Data Cloud

Let's see how BDC is built and how the key components that make it work and how they fit together.

One of the most interesting things about SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) is that it doesn't start from scratch. It combines some of SAP's most proven existing technologies with brand new innovations designed for the data and AI era.

Let's understand the existing SAP solutions that form the foundation. 

SAP Datasphere - This is one of the core data integration and modeling layer of BDC.  It is like a brain that organises, connects, and models all the business data. Datasphere allows you to define data models, map relationships, and create semantic layers that business and technical users can both understand. Itâ€™s the part of the platform that ensures data is structured, contextualized, and ready to use for analytics and AI.

SAP Analytics Cloud - This is the analysis and visualization layer. Itâ€™s where users actually interact with data through dashboards, reports, and planning models. SAC is tightly integrated with BDC.  It provides both out-of-the-box analytical stories and flexible tools for ad-hoc analysis. It even supports AI-driven features like predictive insights and chat-based data exploration, helping users move seamlessly from insight to action.

SAP BW or BW/4HANA -  Many customers already have large investments in BW, and SAP recognized that value. So instead of replacing it, BDC integrates it. BW data objects can be technically onboarded into the Business Data Cloud, as data products and reuse them in new AI and analytics scenarios. SAP plans to support BW until 2030, but the idea is to give customers a smooth modernization path toward BW/4HANA and cloud-native analytics.

Now let's understand the new components introduced specifically for SAP Business Data Cloud. 

SAP Databricks - This is one of the biggest innovations. It brings advanced AI and machine learning capabilities directly into the SAP ecosystem. Databricks has long been a leader in large-scale data processing and pro-code data science, and SAP has now embedded a tailored version inside BDC.
This integration allows data scientists to access and extend data products directly. For example, they can take a data product from SAP Business Data Cloud, enrich it with machine learning models in Databricks, and then push the enhanced insights right back into the BDC catalog or vice versa.

SAP Business Data Cloud Foundation Services - This layer manages the data lifecycle from ingestion and harmonization to transformation and enrichment. When data comes from your source systems (for example, SAP S/4HANA Cloud or SAP SuccessFactors) the Foundation Services replicate it into the BDC environment, which runs on SAP HANA Cloud and hyper-scaler infrastructure. From there, itâ€™s automatically cleansed, harmonized, and turned into something called a data product which a packaged, ready-to-use set of business data.

Conclusion

Now we have covered the Introduction, Why do we need Business Data Cloud, and Key Components of SAP Business Data Cloud. I hope you have got a basic understanding about SAP Business Data Cloud. This is the first part of the blog series.

In the upcoming parts, we will cover the architecture of SAP Business Data Cloud, and understand the main components of BDC in detail.

If you have any questions or queries, please post them as comments. I will try to answer the maximum as per my knowledge.

entry.title: Re: Change Special Procurement in MRP view of material
entry.content:
Hi,

Hope you read help documentation else strongly recommend you to read once:

Special Procurement 20 - Direct Procurement

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ERP/85d3fce10e264972a0155c8b46ecf93b/1bacce5314894208e10000000a174cb4.html 

Special Procurement 70 - Withdrawal from alternate plant

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ERP/85d3fce10e264972a0155c8b46ecf93b/67acce5314894208e10000000a174cb4.html

In case of 20, you are procuring the component and storing & issuing from the same plant. In MRP run, necessary stock reservation and if required Purchase requisition is created.

In case of 70, the component is issued from another plant. When you run MRP, this component is not planned in MRP run plant but planned in the issuing plant (a reservation is created in issuing plant & when you run MRP in that plant, it creates planned order or purchase requisition as per material master). Typically done when both plants are in same location. Different plants might have been created at same location for some reason (tax/reporting/SBU design).  This type is used in such cases to avoid creation & execution of stock transport order.

Trust this helps

entry.title: Integrating Platform Events using Salesforce PubSub Adapter in SAP Cloud Integration
entry.content:
In this post, we will explore how to use the Salesforce PubSub adapter in SAP Cloud Integration (SAP CI) to subscribe to Platform Events in Salesforce. This approach enables real-time, event-driven communication between Salesforce and external systems without the need for frequent polling or API calls.

What is the Salesforce PubSub Adapter (Sender)?

The Salesforce Pub/Sub Sender Adapter uses the Pub/Sub API, built on the gRPC protocol. It allows SAP CI to listen to Salesforce event streams in real time. Instead of polling for changes or using REST API calls, this adapter maintains a persistent connection to Salesforceâ€™s event bus, capturing events as they occur.

What are Platform Events?

Platform Events in Salesforce provide an event-driven mechanism to exchange data inside and outside Salesforce in real time. Instead of continuously querying Salesforce for changes, external systems like SAP CI can subscribe to Platform Events and react immediately when specific business conditions occur. This results in faster, cleaner, and more scalable integrations.

The true power of Platform Events lies in their ability to capture only the relevant business signals. Unlike Change Data Capture, which publishes every record change, Platform Events allow you to include only required fields, apply qualification rules, and fire events only when specific business conditions are met. This ensures cleaner, lighter, and more meaningful integrations â€” especially in event-driven scenarios where SAP CI needs to react only to critical events rather than process noise.

Creating a Platform Event in Salesforce

Letâ€™s create a sample Platform Event for the Account object. This event will send qualified Account data.

  1. Navigate to Setup â†’ Quick Find â†’ Platform Events â†’ New Platform Event.
  2. Fill in the details:
      â€¢ Singular Label: AccountPlatformEvent
      â€¢ Plural Label: Accounts
      â€¢ API Name: AccountPlatformEvent__e
      â€¢ Description: Event to send qualified Accounts to External system.
      â€¢ Leave default retention (72 hours).
  3. Create required custom fields (example):
      â€¢ AccountId__c â€“ Text(18)
      â€¢ Name__c â€“ Text(255)
      â€¢ Industry__c â€“ Text(50)
      â€¢ Rating__c â€“ Text(50)

These fields define the schema of your event messages.

Publishing Platform Events Using Apex

Next, we will publish the Platform Event whenever an Account record is created or updated. Below is a sample Apex trigger that publishes an event message, it can be created from Developer console of the Salesforce.

trigger AccountPlatformEventPublisher on Account (after insert, after update) {
    List<AccountPlatformEvent__e> events = new List<AccountPlatformEvent__e>();
    for (Account acc : Trigger.new) {
        events.add(new AccountPlatformEvent__e(
            AccountId__c        = acc.Id,
            AccountSource__c    = acc.AccountSource,
            AnnualRevenue__c    = acc.AnnualRevenue,
            BillingCity__c      = acc.BillingCity,
            BillingCountry__c   = acc.BillingCountry,
            BillingStreet__c    = acc.BillingStreet,
            CreatedDate__c      = acc.CreatedDate,
            CurrencyIsoCode__c  = acc.CurrencyIsoCode,
            Industry__c         = acc.Industry,
            IsDeleted__c        = String.valueOf(acc.IsDeleted),
            LastModifiedDate__c = acc.LastModifiedDate,
            Name__c             = acc.Name,
            Rating__c           = acc.Rating,
            SAPCustomerNumber__c= acc.SAPCustomerNumber__c
        ));
    }
    if (!events.isEmpty()) {
        Database.SaveResult[] results = EventBus.publish(events);
        System.debug('Published ' + results.size() + ' Account events.');
    }
}

Subscribing to Platform Events Using the PubSub Adapter

Once the Platform Event is created, configure the Salesforce Pub/Sub Sender adapter in SAP CI to subscribe to the event channel. Below are key features and configuration parameters:

  • Subscribe to Salesforce channels to receive events.
  • Supports publishing of events to channels with defined schemas.
  • Retrieve schemas using the 'Get Schema' operation.
  • Support for OAuth 2.0 Username-Password and OAuth 2.0 JWT Bearer authentication.
  • Replay options to control event retrieval (Earliest, Latest, Custom).
  • Error handling and re-subscription mechanisms.

 Below is the detailed description of each parameter used in this iflow covering Salesforce PubSub adapter.

We are using sender Salesforce PubSub adapter to consume the platform events, configurations are as below.

SAP CI Iflow:

Sender : Pick a sender from the pallet and select the Salesforce Pub Sub Adapter from the adapter list

Configuration of Salesforce Pub Sub Sender Adapter:

Parameter Description:

Host

Specify the host to which the proxy requests are sent for the gRPC API (towards the gRPC host). The proxy requests to the gRPC host will go through the proxy. Example: api.pubsub.salesforce.com

Port

Specify the port to which the proxy requests are sent for the gRPC API (towards the gRPC port). The proxy requests to the gRPC port will go through the proxy. Example: 7443

Tenant ID

Specify the Salesforce Organization ID, this can be found in Company Information within the "Setup" page on Salesforce

Authentication

Select the authentication type to be used for the connection to Salesforce:

  • OAuth 2.0 Username-Password
  • OAuth 2.0 JWT Bearer
â„¹ï¸The following fields are available when OAuth 2.0 JWT Bearer is selected.

Token URL

Specify the login endpoint to your Salesforce instance url. Example: https://login.salesforce.com for Salesforce production environment, https://test.salesforce.com for Salesforce Sandbox environment and https://{MyDomain}.my.salesforce.com in case MyDomain is enabled on the org.

Credential Name

Specify the User Credentials storing the username-password details.

Security Token Alias

Specify the Security Token Alias that refers to the secure parameter.

This can be omitted if your SAP CI IP address has been whitelisted in Salesforce

OAuth Credential Name

Specify the User Credentials that stores the Consumer key-Client secret pair.

â„¹ï¸The following fields are available when OAuth 2.0 JWT Bearer is selected.

Audience

Specify the login endpoint to your Salesforce instance URL. Example: https://login.salesforce.com for Salesforce production environment, https://test.salesforce.com for Salesforce Sandbox environment, and https://site.force.com/customers if implementing for an Experience Cloud site

Subject Alias

Specify the Secure Parmeter that stores the username of the Salesforce user.

Issuer Alias

Specify the Secure Parameter which indicates the OAuth client_id of the connected app in Salesforce for which the certificate was registered.

Keystore Alias

Specify the alias name of the added JKS file in Keystore as a Key Pair. It consists of a key and certificate to sign the JWT

Expiration (in ms)

Specifies the validity of the assertion in milliseconds

 Processing Tab:

 

Channel NameSpecify the Salesforce channel name to perform the subscription. (here we will use the /event/ and then the API name of the Platform event created in previous steps in Salesfoce.)
Replay ID Approach

Select the replay option in the first FetchRequest:

  • Events from a specific position (Custom) 
  • Events from earliest position (Earliest) â€¢
  • Events from latest position (Latest) The default value is Events from latest position (Latest) which allows subscription only to new event messages and does not retrieve earlier event messages stored in the event bus

Replay ID

Specify the Replay ID value. The Replay ID is populated by Salesforce and refers to the position of the event in the event stream. Example: 8381402

Request Batch Size

Specify the number of events to be requested in the Salesforce fetchRequest. The default value is 100

Replay Preset for Invalid Replay ID

Select the replay option in case â€œsfdc.platform.eventbus.grpc.subscription.fetch.replayid.corruptedâ€ error occurs:

  • Events from latest position (Latest)
  • Events from earliest position (Earliest) The default value is Events from earliest position (Earliest) indicating the earlier event messages stored in the event bus.

Duplicate Check Expiration (in ms)

Specify the expiry time in milliseconds while handling the Duplicate check. The default value is 300000

Process Errors as an Event

Enable this property to write error events in the exchange. If disabled, issues connecting to event streams will only be written to the logs

Deployment of the IFlow:

Now lets deploy the IFlow and see how this works, For demostration, I will create the Account record and then update it.

Demo:

New account created in Salesforce:

As soon the record is saved in the Salesforce, the event/message is generated which is received by SAP CI

{
  "payload": {
    "AccountId__c": "001J100000X6REOIA3",
    "AnnualRevenue__c": 10000,
    "CurrencyIsoCode__c": "USD",
    "Name__c": "Test Account For Demo",
    "BillingCountry__c": "India",
    "Industry__c": "Finance",
    "AccountSource__c": null,
    "CreatedDate__c": 1760449971000,
    "CreatedById": "0055g00000AqVaAAAV",
    "SAPCustomerNumber__c": "101",
    "CreatedDate": 1760449971276,
    "BillingStreet__c": "ABC Road",
    "LastModifiedDate__c": 1760449971000,
    "Rating__c": "Warm",
    "IsDeleted__c": "false",
    "BillingCity__c": "Pune"
  },
  "schemaId": "3lrXZmbw8vDsOdsDj74Qpw",
  "id": "644d0292-d8b7-4fd4-9c5d-5f64eefb7bca"
}

Now lets update the Account and see the event, I will update the name and the City

New event received in SAP CI

In order to see the replay Id of the event we need to check the headers after the Salesforce PubSub adapter step:

Replay Id when Account was created:

Replay Id of the update event:

Observations

  • Only the fields defined in the Platform Event schema are included in the payload. 
  • Each update triggers the transmission of the complete message again.

Conclusion

Using Salesforce Platform Events with the SAP CI PubSub adapter enables truly event-driven integrations between Salesforce and external systems. By defining only the necessary fields and publishing them through an Apex trigger, you ensure that downstream systems receive lean, relevant data instead of full records. The Pub/Sub adapter maintains a persistent gRPC connection for real-time delivery, minimizing API usage and latency. This approach provides a scalable, reliable, and modern integration pattern for enterprise-grade Salesforce-to-SAP scenarios.

Thanks,

Manish Deshpande

entry.title: When â€œAdd Columnsâ€ Broke My Brain: Basic CAP + BAS + Fiori Elements
entry.content:
1 â€“ Setting the Scene

I spun up a new CAP project in SAP Business Application Studio and thought:
â€œHow hard can it be to show a list of incidents from a SQLite database?â€

IncidentManagementCAP/
â”œâ”€ db/schema.cds
â”œâ”€ srv/incidentsrv.cds
â””â”€ package.json

schema.cds defined the usual suspects â€” Incidents, Customers, Status, Urgency.
incidentsrv.cds exposed them through an IncidentService.
SQLite was configured as persistence.

2 â€“ CAPâ€™s Circle of Errors

Act 1:

[ERROR] Mismatched â€¹Identifierâ€º, expecting â€¹Stringâ€º

BAS had â€œhelpfullyâ€ converted my straight quotes into curly ones. Replacing them with normal ASCII quotes fixed it.

Act 2:

no such table: IncidentService_Incidents

Iâ€™d only deployed the db model, not the srv one, so the projection view didnâ€™t exist. Adding this to package.json fixed it:

{
  "cds": {
    "requires": {
      "db": {
        "kind": "sqlite",
        "credentials": { "database": "db.sqlite" },
        "model": [ "db", "srv" ]
      }
    }
  }
}
cds deploy --to sqlite

Act 3: BAS uses an in-memory SQLite DB by default, so every restart wiped my tables. Pointing to a real file finally made data persist.

3 â€“ Success (Sort of)

/> successfully deployed to db.sqlite

and:

IncidentService_Incidents
sap_capire_incidents_Incidents

Progress! I opened the preview app expecting rows of data â€¦ and got a pristine white screen reading:

Add columns to see the content

Nothing wrong with my code; Fiori Elements was just hiding every field until I manually selected them.

4 â€“ The Real Fix

  1. In the Data Preview, click the âš™ï¸ gear icon.
  2. Choose Table Settings â†’ Columns.
  3. Tick ID, title, status_code, urgency_code.
  4. Click Apply.

Suddenly the data appeared â€” the record Iâ€™d seeded in sap.capire.incidents-Incidents.csv.
After days of chasing ghosts, it all came down to a UI checkbox.

5 â€“ Lessons Learned

  • Curly quotes and BOMs: BAS sneaks them in; CAP chokes on them. Type the using ... from "../db/schema"; line manually.
  • Deploy both models (db, srv), not just the schema.
  • Use a real SQLite file in package.json; in-memory DBs reset on each run.
  • That â€œAdd Columnsâ€ message isnâ€™t an error. Itâ€™s Fiori Elements politely saying â€œIâ€™m empty until you tell me what to show.â€

6 â€“ Takeaway

Sometimes CAP isnâ€™t broken â€” itâ€™s just very literal. Between invisible characters, hidden tables, and silent checkboxes, getting to that first visible row can feel absurd. But once youâ€™ve fought through it, you understand how the layers fit together:

Layer Purpose

db/Entities and persistence
srv/OData service / projections
app/Fiori Elements UI
package.jsonThe glue holding it together

So when someone in the forums says â€œMy CAP service returns nothing,â€ youâ€™ll smile knowingly and reply: â€œCheck your quotes. Then click Add Columns.â€

entry.title: Material Interchangeability During Goods Receipt
entry.content:
Material interchangeability in SAP MM allows users to substitute or replace materials in purchasing documents. This functionality enables flexibility in procurement processes, allowing purchase requisitions to be created with one material number and replaced with another that has similar characteristics during quotation or while posting goods receipt.

let's discuses the process for exchange during goods receipt

Define Manufacturer Part no. Indicator

Path: SPRO > Logistic General > Material Master > Basic Setting > Make Global Setting >
Set the "Manufacturer part no" indicator: Enable

 

 

 

Define manufacturer part profiles
â€¢ Path: SPRO > Material Management > Purchasing > Material Master > Define manufacture part profile

  • Action: Create a profile and select the "Inventory-Managed Manuf. Part." indicator. This profile will be assigned to all interchangeable materials > then Save.

 

 

 

Define settings for material replacement in MIGO.

  • Path: SPRO > Logistic General > Interchangeability of parts > Define Settings for Material Exchange and Restricted Interchangeability
  • Action: Double-click on the "ME-MIGO-MIGO_GI" entry and configure the settings for automatic material exchange during goods receipt. When finished, the "Automatic material exchange" column for MIGO will be changed to "Yes"

 

 

 

And same for Migo_GR

Note: if you did not find MIGO_GR you can add it form New Entries

 

Set up screen for material replacement in goods movement.

  • Path: SPRO > Logistic General > Interchangeability of parts > setup screen for material replacement in goods movement
  • Action: Add your profile and assign the relevant users and plants

 

 

                   Important note : you need to add authorization object to your user profile â€œM_PIC_EXCHâ€

 

Create FFF Class Material >> MM01

Material type: FFFC

Select basic data 1

Assign manufacturer part profile and bas unit of measure

 

 

 

 

Create your own materials (Raw, Spare parts, etc...) with required views and assign Mfr Part Profile on purchasing view

Create interchangeability materials with material type ( HERB )

Here mfr part number is mandatory and it will same material number

Fill the required data and assign Mfr Part Profile on purchasing view

 

 

MPN Interchangeability Set Creation. Tcode >> PIC01

Insert material with FFF Class as created before

 

 

 

Assign main and interchangeability materials and save

 

click on MPN-MPR sets icon/tab

Maintain set ( plant â€“ MRP Area â€“ Materials )

Set check box for leading material ( main item ) then save

 

 

Now you can Create :

  • Info record for interchangeability materials
  • Create Purchase Order with Main Item

 

Po created with main item

 

Create a goods receipt reference to purchase order through MIGO

Now material exchange tab has been applied ... click on tab

 

 

 

Enter the required qty for main or interchangeability materials or both

Click Post

 

 

Material document posted

Letâ€™s check the po

 

System has created 2 new line items first for remaining qty and another one for interchangeability material with price form info record

Should you have any questions regarding this document, please do not hesitate to reach out
I hope you find this document helpful

entry.title: SAP Ariba, SAP Fieldglass and SAP S/4HANA ERP solutions for public healthcare
entry.content:
Author: Allan Soo

Introduction

Healthcare public sector procurement spend is among the largest across the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD). In 2021, 31.9% of all public procurement spend touches on public healthcare and infrastructure [1]. Nearly 75% of public spend on healthcare came from taxpayers [2]. With an ageing population and a shrinking taxpayer base, governments across the world are grappling with these fiscal challenges. One solution is to deploy effective spend management, procurement solutions across cost-intensive sectors of the economy to keep costs down.

Figure depicting the percentage government expenditure across the OECD-EU countries for 2023 [3]. Public sector procurement across the OECD-EU markets was 14.7% (2023), an increase of 0.9% compared to 2019.  

Why an effective, public procurement platform is crucial for public healthcare and governments?

Public procurement in healthcare is one of the most regulated forms of purchasing dealing with hospitals, pharmacies, and qualified suppliers. This requires complex compliance to purchasing pharmaceutical ingredients, chemicals and other regulated products to be compliant to public healthcare agencies. An example is the procurement of surgical implants and tools which must comply with the Therapeutic Goods Association (TGA) and other dangerous goods regulations.

Healthcare public procurement is becoming a significant challenge for governments worldwide due to factors such as an ageing population, rising deficits and total debts, the high costs of running healthcare facilities, and increased health and safety regulations.

Track spend and compliance across cost-intensive healthcare segments by different categories with SAP Ariba Category Management, SAP Ariba Intake Management and SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle Performance Management

SAP Ariba Category Management gives public sector healthcare purchasers the tools to track spend goals on their most cost-intensive areas of their agency including high-tech equipment, specialized hospital beds, pharmaceutical purchases and more.

The solution gives public healthcare purchasers the option to manage supplier performance and track these against budgets, manage funds and investments assigned and set to them by the government.

The solution also offers customers a 360-degree visibility into the supplierâ€™s healthcare certifications and qualifications, making sure that they comply to directives and maximize compliance across all purchases made for the public facilities. For example, Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) license for Australia, Wholesale Distribution Authorisation for EU suppliers supplying medicinal products, and Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency certification for medicinal product manufacturing in the United Kingdom.

Adverse events can then be monitored using SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance Management to manage supplier risks appropriately. 3rd party data such as D&B can give government buyers additional intelligence on the market risk of that supplier such as sustainability, supply chain exposure, and aid in calculating inherent and residual risk scoringâ€¦and so on. Up to 25 custom risk scores can be applied to the healthcare supplier in SAP Ariba Supplier Risk.

Renegotiate and manage multiple quotes across healthcare suppliers to drive cost savings with finance

To keep costs down, buyers have the ability with SAP Ariba Sourcing and Procurement for Public Sector in SAP S/4HANA, to manage different quotes and renegotiate prices with existing suppliers to obtain better deals. For example, evaluating the procurement of multiple MRI and X-ray machines, and different existing drug prices to encourage better competition between pharmaceutical suppliers to drive down prices.

Buyers can take advantage of the SAP Taulia Private Cloud solution with SAP S/4HANA and Dynamic Discounting feature where fast, early account payable transactions towards suppliers can lead to discounted cash savings that yield improved bottom line benefits for public healthcare finance customers.

Connect SAP Ariba Sourcing and SAP Ariba Buying solutions to the SAP S/4HANA ERP for high-level spend management and monitoring

Go beyond purchasing and ordering with high-level dashboard spend visibility [4] to track the list of purchase orders with SAP Ariba Central Procurement with SAP Ariba Buying (3EN) and SAP Ariba Buying, with guided buying capabilities (2NV) into SAP S/4HANA. Easily track the process flow of your purchases and export accounting documents to SAP finance and accounting solutions. Use three-way matching against invoice, purchase order and goods receipt to ensure that cost information is accurate. Request quotes from suppliers, allocate budget and discuss on pricing terms.

One highly relevant area for this is the operational procurement of medical apparel, protective equipment, gloves and face masks. You as the buyer want the tools to negotiate with suppliers on favorable pricing terms, sort price lists in Catalogs available over the SAP Business Network, and see the list of purchase orders, invoices and goods receipts in one place. You can set estimated budgets throughout the quotation process and track how far below under the target price you are able to get the costs down to attain cost savings.

Figure showing SAP Ariba Buying and Invoicing solution where healthcare purchasers can track how far below taxpayer funded budget they can obtain when purchasing medical supplies like gloves.

With these solutions, healthcare public sector buyers and public finance can move away from matching for accuracies and scrutinize cost details on these items and work collaboratively with other departments to find alternative suppliers and products that offer cheaper and better-quality substitutes.  

Leverage AI solutions for contracts management

SAP Ariba Contract Intelligence by Icertis SolEx has contract authoring capabilities that are bolstered by AI to automate much of the clause generation that is in line with the public healthcare industry and to drive compliance. Examples can include authoring in sustainability criteria, medical manufacturing license requirements from suppliers, and assigning responsibilities on direct suppliers and their affiliates. By automating the contract lifecycle, lead times can be reduced and anomalies within contract clauses can be detected and flagged for risk mitigation. The solution helps users identify contract leakage risks to prevent cost blowouts and put boundaries on spend conditions for public healthcare purchases. Risk scores on suppliers can be imported from SAP Ariba Supplier Risk to SAP Ariba Contracts to guide contract awarding decisions so that risk-aware awarding decisions can be made. Managing suppliers is part of the public sector procurement responsibility to ensure that government healthcare agencies continue receiving the best outcomes for the budget they are given with the right contracts in place.

Put cost guardrails on healthcare goods and services procured

With WK value contracts [5] in SAP S/4HANA, SAP Ariba Contracts [6] users can set guardrails against overspending on suppliers. Given that in healthcare settings the quantity of goods can be non-negotiable, SAP Ariba Contracts offers the flexibility to adjust quantity (through quantity contracts) and assign other attributes such as discounts on purchased goods through supplier collaboration and negotiations. Buyers can set cost parameters on the value contracts and publish it through the Cloud Integration Gateway to SAP S/4HANA. Purchase cost data can then be ingested by finance solutions to monitor and act on the financial performance of the health agency.

Smart Peppol invoicing with SAP S/4HANA and SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management

With eInvoicing solutions offered with SAP Documents and Reporting Compliance (cloud edition) within S/4HANA ERP Public Cloud Edition, SAP Business Network via SAP Integration Suite, and SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management - Peppol compliant documents can be exchanged to help government healthcare sectors align with eInvoicing compliance requirements or eliminate the use of physical paper. Eliminating physical paperwork and complying to Peppol eInvoicing means enhancing fraud-prevention systems in place to build trust with the public and install financial protections, improves productivity and minimizes errors in costing amounts.  Peppol is used by over 40 countries worldwide for business-to-government transactions, and is becoming a standardized, secure method of receiving invoices from the private sector supplier base by government agencies. Public hospitals and other healthcare agencies can examine and analyze invoice costs based on the high-fidelity information supplied electronically within the system, making it easily auditable for finance.

AI-driven Statement of Work (SOW) creations in SAP Fieldglass to alleviate workloads and focus on the things that matter

Minimize admin work and hire contractors to help comply to a variety of laws during the SOW creation process. Use the GenAI solution at SAP to identify opportunities to control costs during the SOW creation and reduce document creation times by about 71% by inputting titles, summaries and extracting data from PDF documents. With freed-up workloads, users can focus on the quality, risk and service traits of the contract (such as proper skills matching for best labour productivity outcomes). An example includes SOW creation for biohazardous health waste disposal services and scoping the boundaries of work, and clearly stating what services are in and out of scope and using SOW teams feature to collaborate with non-procurement colleagues on budget planning with finance that addresses high-spend service categories.

Improved SOW rates negotiation and cost management features on contracted services

Service buyers can negotiate for better rates post-agreement, automate offboarding signatures to cease spend, ensure hours worked are fulfilled by the contractors, reallocation of unspent SOW funds back to master SOW, inactivate cost centers when they are no longer used, and trigger alerts when rates vary away from agreed ones. These are features that are offered by SAP Fieldglass to service buyers in public healthcare settings to put a lid on costs.

Picture this, you need to onboard technicians to provide maintenance and calibration services for the complex equipment that the hospital has. Your rates need to be specified clearly, and any pay deviations need to be notified to the service buyer, clear start-end dates for the services and so on need to be in the SOW for legal reasons. You use the GenAI feature to produce an SOW quickly, double check the contents of this document, and have the work order issued. Skills are clearly specified for the job to minimize lead times onsite, and the best labour-hire is made. Therefore, costs are controlled, and the best productivity is obtained for maintenance work at the hospital.

Support green procurement practices

SAP Ariba Sourcing integrates with the suite of SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP sustainability solutions to drive green procurement practices across the public healthcare sector. Given that Scope 3 contributes to around 79% of total carbon emissions [7] for this sector across the OECD markets, governments can use SAP tools to drive sustainable procurement practices on their direct suppliers. Examples including procuring gloves with a low product carbon footprint, high recycled content, and rubber data to ensure that illegal deforestation has not contributed to its production.

Alongside SAP Ariba Supplier Management, SAP Fieldglass and SAP Ariba Contracts, public healthcare sectors can manage risk appropriately and enforce sustainability practices and compliance on suppliers and contractors. This includes due diligence screening solutions on a supplierâ€™s human rights and deforestation records, having the right sustainability credentials, and embedding sustainability due diligence into the core operational and strategic sourcing processes from procurement to the ERP environment. Given the mandates that governments must meet for their own net-zero, human rights and material circularity directives - SAP Ariba, SAP Fieldglass and SAP ERP Sustainability solutions provide a comprehensive suite of products to drive decarbonization and compliance in the public healthcare space. Partner solutions on the SAP app store can be used to enrich supplier data with sustainability scores and other external intel.

Tap into the SAP Spend Intelligence in SAP Business Data Cloud solution for rich data reporting on procurement spend

Enrich healthcare spend data with other SAP Business Data Cloud products to gain deeper insights into the entire healthcare organizationâ€™s finance and spend data. SAP Spend Intelligence offers customers a large variety of data products it can ingest. For example, sustainability, risk, contract leakages and off-contract purchase order spend.  By providing strategic and operational insights into a public healthcareâ€™s spend, buyers can optimize for and eliminate out non-compliance and uses AI and machine learning to automatically allocate spend categories neatly for interpretation. SAP Joule can be employed to clean and present cluttered data in a meaningful way that helps drive high-level decision-making processes which maximizes healthcare spend impacts and cuts down maverick and unwanted tail spend.

Conclusion

SAP Ariba, SAP Fieldglass and SAP S/4HANA ERP solutions provide finance and spend management solutions that offer customers the tools to keep up to date with the latest innovations in driving cost savings, optimize spend, manage down risks, reduce fraud and work collaboratively with public sector finance teams in government. Given the significance of public healthcare sectors across developed markets, innovative procurement spend management solutions play a key role in controlling costs in a high-expenditure industry. For years to come, healthcare expenses are projected to increase with an ageing population, rising deficits and living cost challenges.

This requires a comprehensive, suite of solutions for the public sector that leverages best-of-breed AI and solution offerings that advance the modernization of public sector procurement and finance operations. Governments have a responsibility to foster trust, comply to own directives, address fiscal challenges across the economy for the wellbeing of citizens, and deliver services cost-effectively to the public.

entry.title: Re: SAC: Unable to open private Bookmark after story conv...
entry.content:
@Dustin as you said it works for your colleague and not you, I am taking a wild guess that it could be a caching issue. 

  1. Try clearing your browser cache, using a different browser or incognito mode to see if that fixes the issue. 
  2. Try making a small edit to the story like changing a chart title, or moving a chart a little and then saving the story. This is what the error message tells you by "Please try refreshing the story, modifying the story and trying again". When you make a change and save the story, the stories metadata gets refreshed and sometimes that fixes some of these issues. 
  3. If these steps do not work, open a support incident with SAP Support, referencing SAP Note 3409867.

entry.title: STVARVC in BW Bridge?

entry.title: Alternative Process for Reverse Factoring in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition without Scope Item 4AV
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I have a question regarding the implementation of a reverse factoring process in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

**Background:**
- Customer uses reverse factoring (supply chain finance)
- Dedicated scope item 4AV has been scoped out based on customer requirements
- Manual workaround using standard apps and postings is preferred

**Business Flow:**
1. Invoice received from supplier: Â¥1,000,000 (accounts payable created)
2. Customer requests reverse factoring from factoring company
3. Factoring company pays supplier: Â¥950,000 (Â¥50,000 factoring fee deducted from supplier)
4. Customer pays factoring company on extended payment date: Â¥1,000,000

**Proposed Accounting Entries:**

1. AP creation (Feb 10):
DR: Expense 1,000,000
CR: Accounts Payable (Supplier account) 1,000,000
â†’ App: Supplier Invoicing (MIRO equivalent)

2. Factoring company pays supplier (Feb 15):
DR: Accounts Payable (Supplier account) 1,000,000
CR: Accounts Payable (Factoring company account) 1,000,000
â†’ App: Manual Journal Entry (FB01 equivalent)?
*Or should this clear the supplier AP and create a new AP to factoring company?*

3. Payment to factoring company on extended due date (Apr 30):
DR: Accounts Payable (Factoring company account) 1,000,000
CR: Bank 1,000,000
â†’ App: Post Outgoing Payments (F-53 equivalent)

**Questions:**

1. Is this flow technically feasible in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition? Are the App IDs I mentioned correct, or should I use different apps?

2. What is the correct way to handle the AP transfer from supplier to factoring company in step 2? Should I:
- Use manual journal entry to transfer AP between vendors?
- Clear supplier AP and create new AP document for factoring company?
- Use a different approach?

3. How should we manage the factoring fee (Â¥50,000)? Should it be:
- Recorded separately when payment occurs?
- Included in the initial AP transfer entry?
- Not recorded by customer at all (since supplier bears the cost)?

4. Are there any special master data settings required for reverse factoring suppliers (e.g., payment terms, vendor account groups, or other configurations)?

5. If this approach is not possible, what alternative process would you recommend? Please include:
- Which apps to use (with App IDs if possible)
- Accounting entries for each step
- Master data setup requirements

Any guidance would be greatly appreciated!

Best regards

Hello Qingxi, 

The reason why you are unable to raise request 'Change Hyperscaler AWS Transit Gateway/ TGW Peering/Cloud WAN' is because you don't have the necessary authorization to do so.

In order to submit a service request for the 'Change Hyperscaler AWS Transit Gateway/ TGW Peering/Cloud WAN' template, an S-user must have the authorization 'Create Billable Service Requests' at the customer number level.

Upon reviewing your S-user ID, I found that the required authorization was only assigned at the installation level. Usually, you will need to contact your administrator listed in Users & Contacts - SAP for Me to have the authorization assigned.

For more detailed information on S-user authorizations required the Private Cloud Service Request application, please refer to KBA 2669783 - S-user authorizations required for the Private Cloud Service Request application - SAP for... 

Best regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Pricing procedure in Purchase Contracts
entry.content:
Hi,

If you see standard SAP Pricing procedure RM0000, you see two gross price conditions - PB00 and PBXX

In PB00 settings, you can see a calculation schema RM0002 assigned. 

RM0002 includes supplementary pricing conditions (Discounts, Delivery etc). If you defined any new condition types and included in your pricing procedure, then see that they are included here too. Then you can see them in RFQ & Contracts too. 

For Header/Item conditions :

- Condition type to be defined as both Header and Item in condition type settings

- Group Condition : If you do not check this box, then absolute header condition value is copied in all items. If it's checked, then Absolute Value given in Header is apportioned according to value of each item w.r.t total of all items. Or you can define a routine and assign in config according to which header value is apportioned to items. Note that this also influences how pricing scales determine PO Item price (based on total group value instead of individual item value which is beneficial)

If you configured a custom pricing procedure, ensure you have similar condition type setup as PB00 for your automatic gross price condition type (e.g. ZB00) and assign a calculation schema (e.g. RM0002 or ZM0002) in that (ZB00) as explained above.   If you have used custom schema for Supplementary conditions ZM0002 define it similar to RM0002 and add your additional condition types as required. 

Suggest you to try in Sandbox and explore until you get what you want. 

Trust this helps

entry.title: Why are Consumption Mode and Consumption Period fields missing in â€œManage Product Master Dataâ€ App
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I am working on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and I found an inconsistency between two apps for maintaining product master data.

In the â€œManage Product Master Dataâ€ app (used by business users), the following MRP fields are not available under Planning/MRP views:

  • Consumption Mode

  • Forward Consumption Period

  • Backward Consumption Period

  • MRP Group related consumption settings

  • Other detailed MRP3 control fields

However, in the â€œChange Material / Manage Material Master (MM02)â€ expert app, these fields are available, and we can maintain consumption settings normally (e.g., Strategy 40 / 70 materials).

My question

Is this behavior expected in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition?
Why are these consumption-related fields completely missing from Manage Product Master Data, even when the material uses strategy groups that require consumption (40, 70, B6, etc.)?

What we have checked

  • MRP Type = PD

  • Strategy Group = 40 / 70

  • All relevant master data settings exist

  • The fields appear correctly in the expert material app (MM02)

  • No option to enable these fields through Custom Fields & Logic (CFL)

  • No obvious setting in SSCUI or configuration to expose these fields

Business Impact

Business users need to maintain consumption settings, but they can only use Manage Product Master Data, and the app does not provide these fields.
We want to understand if:

  1. This is SAPâ€™s intended design (only expert app can maintain consumption settings),
    or

  2. If there is a way to make the missing fields available in the simplified master data app.

âœ” Question to SAP / Community

  • Is this a known limitation of the â€œManage Product Master Dataâ€ app?

  • Is there any official documentation explaining which MRP fields are intentionally restricted in this app?

  • Is there a recommended way to allow business users to maintain consumption mode/period?

  • Do we need to assign a specific business role (e.g., SAP_BR_PRODMASTER_SPECIALIST) to make these fields appear?

Any guidance or confirmation from SAP or other practitioners would be greatly appreciated!

Thank you.

entry.title: Re: ğŸ“¢ Survey: ABAP Naming Conventions
entry.content:
Hi Kilian, 

honestly, make it as flexible as possible.

One central maintenance app to define naming conventions:

  1. Define the actual naming convention (within ABAP: declarations, parameters, variables, ...; DDIC objects; global development objects (classes, interfaces, bdef, cds, ...)
  2. Define naming convention level: Package or Object
  3. Define naming convention check type: compile time as syntax error or ATC finding
    1. Option for both: overwriteable-by-pragma true/false
  4. Assign naming convention to package or object

Provide the app as Fiori and SAPGUI app and make it downwards-compatible to including EHP8. 


from that ...
optional features: defining naming convention on object level (might be too granular for most use cases) and issuing it as ATC finding

non-negotiable features: on package level and as compile-time-check

entry.title: Proposals for Matching Certificate Receipts in SAP Cloud ERP 2508.3 (HFC10)
entry.content:
As part of our commitment to continuous innovate; I would like to draw your attention to the latest innovation for the 2508.3 (HFC10) release in Quality Management. Here, I would like to introduce a powerful enhancement to simplify how you manage incoming quality certificates. 

 
We understand that a common challenge in quality management is the manual work required to link an incoming quality certificate to the correct goods receipt, especially when the system cannot make an automatic match. A missing purchase order number or a minor data discrepancy could previously stop the automated process, forcing a user to manually investigate and link the document.

With the new AI-assisted capability coming with 2508.3 (HFC 10),  the system now acts as your intelligent assistant. If a certificate cannot be automatically matched due to insufficient data, the system doesn't just stop. Instead, it uses the data it has successfully extracted such as the material, batch, or supplier to propose a list of potential certificate receipts.
 
List of potential certificate receipts

 

Inside the Review Certificate Document Matches app, you will find a new section dedicated to these proposed matches. Now, instead of starting a manual search from scratch, you can simply review the system's suggestions. Accepting a correct match is a one-click action that attaches the certificate to the corresponding receipt and updates all relevant data. This transforms a tedious manual search into a simple and quick validation step, significantly reducing the risk of errors and freeing up your quality team to focus on more strategic tasks. 
 
You can watch the new matching feature in this demo: 

 

 
Click here to find further details about the Integration of Document AI. 
 
Take care and till the next update! 
Markus

entry.title: MRP Does not calculate the maximum values for ZB Type
entry.content:
Both Cost Center and Work Orders taken into consideration when MRP determines Reorder Qty (Planned Order Qty)

 

1012120 = Stores Stock is 8, Max/Min is 12/6. Reservation on Work Order for 3.

      MRP runs in the evening. Planned Order issued for Qty 4 (When the 3 are removed from stores it leaves 5, when the 4 are delivered we would have 9 in stores) Max is 12

      The reorder qty should have been 7 (not 6) so that qty in stores would be at Max of 12.

 

10123922 = Stores Stock is 30, Max/Min is 40/10. Reservation on Work Order for 80.

      MRP runs. Planned Order issued for Qty 60. (Upon receipt of the 60 ordered, the qty 80 will be goods issued from the storeroom leaving a qty of 10 in the storeroom.

The Reorder qty should have been Qty 90 (90 + 30 in stores = 120, once the 90 order are GR into stores, 90 + 30 in stores =120.) The reserved qty of 80 would be goods issued leaving 30   in stores unrestricted stock.

 

10321821 = Stores Stock is 4, Max/Min is 4/2. Reservation on Work Order for 6 & Cost Center Reservation for 3. Total of 9 Reserved. Planned Order issued for Qty of 7

      MRP runs. Planned Order issued for Qty 7. Upon receipt of the 7, the qty of 9 will be goods issued to the two reservations, leaving a qty of 2 in the storeroom.

The Reorder Qty (Planner Order Qty) Should have been 9

 

Can you help us what is missing.

Thanks in Advance.

Thiru

SAP Signavio Process Insights has released lots of SAP out-of-the-box process analysis content in the last releases but there is lots of things going on in the area of adding new capabilities and increasing our user experience.

A good example is the Beta release of AI-powered semantic search which makes finding issues and proposals for process improvement super easy even if you are not yet an SAP expert. With this you can search with terms which are not used in the SAP applications but still find the right process flows, performance indicators and correction recommendations. In the process flows you even get a highlight of the relevant blockers for the search term you have been using. This is possible because we are using the SAP document grounding service which is part of SAP's AI foundation. Furthermore we are working intensively on bringing our two process analysis and mining solutions - SAP Signavio Process Insights and Process Intelligence - even closer together than what you see with Plug&Gain right now. entry.title: SOLUTION ORDER
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is an architecturally innovative ERP solution that addresses the need for businesses to integrate their end-to-end processes. One of the critical components offered by this platform is the Solution Order structure, which consolidates multiple business objects under a single operational document. For example, when a technology company sells a new server to its customers, it can combine the server's installation service, annual maintenance contract, and even a custom software integration project under a single Solution Order. This allows all processes to be easily tracked and managed from one central order document.

1 Solution Order Architecture

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the Solution Order acts as a master document, centrally managing different item categories (e.g., product, service, project, subscription). This structure is designed to support customer-centric, hybrid sales scenarios, in contrast to silo-based order models in traditional systems.

Technically, when a Solution Order master document is created, the system automatically triggers and generates different follow-on documents corresponding to these item categories in the background. For instance:

  • product item transforms into a Sales Order document, initiating relevant logistics processes (shipping, delivery).
  • service item triggers a Service Order or Service Notification document, starting field service management processes.
  • project item links to a Project document, creating work breakdown structures (WBS) and activities within the project management module.
  • subscription item generates a Subscription Contract document, enabling recurring billing processes.

This approach ensures that all these disparate business objects are linked within the document flow, making the Solution Order master document a single operational monitoring point.

2 Technical Differences from Standard Sales Order

The Solution Order offers a more integrated and dynamic data model compared to the traditional Sales Order structure.

  • Data Model and Integration: While a standard sales order typically focuses solely on product management (SD) and logistics processes, the Solution Order leverages SAP S/4HANA's unified data model to combine different modules such as SD, Service, Project Systems (PS), and Subscription Billing into a single process. This ensures data consistency and integrity.
  • API Integration: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is developed with an API-first approach. The Solution Order object can be created and managed via OData services from external systems (e.g., CPQ - Configure, Price, Quote - solutions or custom customer portals). This provides a flexible platform for end-to-end process automation.
  • Billing Processes: While standard sales orders typically generate a single invoice document, the Solution Order can trigger different billing plans with a central billing engine. This allows for managing various billing methods under a single order, such as milestone billing for projects, time-and-materials billing for services, or recurring billing for subscriptions.

3 Advantages and Disadvantages

Advantages

  • Process Orchestration: Enables different business units (sales, finance, project, service) to collaborate in a unified operational process.
  • Data Integrity: Provides a single, consistent view of data as all process documents are linked to one master document.
  • Automation and Scalability: API integration allows for automated document creation and process management with external systems, increasing operational efficiency.

Disadvantages

  • Structural Complexity: The integrated and multi-module nature of the process may require deeper technical knowledge and system configuration during implementation and adaptation phases.
  • Configuration Dependency: Due to the Public Cloud's strategy of adopting standard processes, the flexibility of the Solution Order structure depends on predefined business processes. Custom developments (extensibility) might be limited for highly specific or non-standard processes.

The Solution Order in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud provides a strong foundation for managing the complex and integrated business models required by the digital economy. This structure is a core component of the "Intelligent Enterprise" vision, enabling businesses to enhance customer value by offering integrated solutions rather than merely selling products.

4 Configuration

There are two main customization steps for the solution order. These customizations can be accessed through the following tabs.

Solutions --> Solution Management --> Solution Orders --> Solution Order Management

4.1 Copy Sales Order Type in Solution Orders

With this customization, determination of which sales order document types can be used with reference to a solution order is carried out.

4.2 Copy Item Categories of Sales Items in Solution Orders

With this customization step, it is determined with which order document type and which item category the item category selected in the solution order will be created in the next step.

In this customization, the key fields are the solution order item category and the sales order document type. This means that by assigning two different sales order item categories to a single solution order item category across two different sales order document types, it allows different processes to be executed.

5 Example Process

Within the Manage Solution Orders application, click the New button to navigate to the solution order creation screen.

First, the header information screen appears. On this screen, the customer and the contact person can be selected.

At the item level, a material is entered and in the Item Category column the processes to be followed are selected. Here, a variety of different scenarios can be chosen. The relevant scenarios are as follows:

Rental Item

3rd Party w. SN FoC

FOC MainItmPr. (BOM)

3rd Party with SN

3rd Party w/o SN FoC

Pri. at Subitm (BOM)

3rd Party w/o SN

Bought-In Sales FoC

FOC Pr. at Sub (BOM)

Bought-In Sales Item

Sales f. Service FoC

Log. Item w. Billing

Sales Itm f. Service

Non-Stock Sales FoC

Pric. Head/Log. Item

Non-Stock Sales Item

Explanation in BOM

Head FOC B/Log. Item

Sales Item

Main Itm Price (BOM)

Non-Stock Item

Sales Item FoC

  

As mentioned above, many different detailed pieces of information can be entered; however, the information I have shared above is sufficient to save the solution order.

Once the requested information is entered, click the save button located at the bottom right, and the solution order can be saved.

When attempting to proceed with the steps of the created solution order, enter the solution order, go to the "Items" tab, and once "Release" is clicked, the process steps will automatically progress for each item.

After the release, the documents progressed according to the selected processes, and their display are as follows.

After the sales order is created, the corresponding document follows the exact same process as the SD (Sales and Distribution) process.

6. Conclusion

The Solution Order functionality in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud represents a major step forward in the evolution of enterprise process integration. By consolidating multiple business objectsâ€”products, services, projects, and subscriptionsâ€”under a single operational framework, it enables organizations to deliver holistic, value-driven solutions to their customers rather than isolated products or services.

Through its API-first architecture, modular flexibility, and end-to-end visibility, the Solution Order empowers businesses to orchestrate sales, service, and project operations seamlessly, reducing administrative overhead while enhancing process transparency and customer satisfaction.

While its implementation requires careful configuration and a solid understanding of SAPâ€™s integrated data model, the long-term benefitsâ€”such as consistent data management, improved collaboration across departments, and scalable automationâ€”make it an essential capability for any organization aiming to become an Intelligent Enterprise.

In essence, the Solution Order is not just a technical enhancement; it is a strategic enabler that bridges business innovation with operational excellence, driving the digital transformation journey in the most comprehensive and structured way possible.

entry.title: Resolving Navigation Issues in the ESS Application Using LPD_CUST Configuration in ECC/SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
Hi Everyone,

Iâ€™m writing this blog to share the resolution of an issue I recently encountered in my project. Hopefully, it will help others facing a similar challenge.

 

Issue Details
Working Scenario:
We are using an Employee Self-Service (ESS) Web Dynpro application based on LPD_CUST configuration in an SAP S/4HANA 2023 Rise system (For ECC also it will work).

The application was working perfectly when our portal system and backend system were both using the HTTP protocol, with the connection established through a system alias in the portal.

 

When the Issue Started:
As per the SAP Rise teamâ€™s security guidelines, HTTP access to the S/4HANA system was disabled. Consequently, we had to switch our portal and load balancer configuration to use HTTPS instead, ensuring secure communication with the backend.

After implementing HTTPS, we tested the ESS application. While the Web Dynpro application worked fine in standalone mode, navigation within the portal (e.g., clicking â€œCreate Leave Requestâ€) stopped functioning.

No errors appeared in the browser console or network tab â€” the click simply produced no response from the server. PFA the Screen shot for your reference (ESS Leave Request Application Navigation issue.JPG) .

 

Analysis:
After reviewing multiple blogs and SAP community posts, I came across the following SAP Knowledge Base Article (KBA), which provided the key insight:

SAP KBA: 3369675 - FAQ: Enterprise Portal inner application navigation issues with Google Chrome Version starting 115/116 & Edge Version starting 118/119

According to this KBA, recent updates in Chrome and Edge introduced stricter browser policies affecting inner application navigation within the Enterprise Portal.

 

Resolution:
To resolve the issue, we updated the following parameter in the NWA (NetWeaver Administrator):

Current Value: PFA the Screen shot (Current Value of CustomResponseHeaders.JPG)
CustomResponseHeaders = {X-FRAME-OPTIONS=SAMEORIGIN}

Updated Value: PFA the Screen shot (Updated Value of CustomResponseHeaders.JPG)
CustomResponseHeaders = {Origin-Agent-Cluster=?0}

After applying this change we need to take application restart (All Application Server one by one).

Afte restart the parameter effected and  ESS application navigation started working correctly.

 

Conclusion:
This issue was caused by recent browser security updates impacting portal navigation behavior. Adjusting the response header as per the SAP KBA resolves the issue effectively.

I hope this post helps anyone encountering a similar problem in their SAP environment.

 

Best regards,
Rohit Gera

Dear @PChacon,

Why does activating â€Set Country-Specific Checksâ€ (102592) not change the BP apps?

  • Because it controls backend validation rules only (checks on country-specific fields) and does not add or expose new address fields in Maintain/Manage Business Partner. So the behavior you see is expected.

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2784057

Is there an app equivalent to SR12 to jointly maintain Regions, Provinces, Postal Codes, and Districts for CR & SV?

  • In SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition 2508, no â€“ there is no standard Fiori app like SR12 for public cloud. Only in Private Cloud based on Fiori apps library.

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('S_P7D_67000090')/S31PCE

 

  • The only self-service configuration you have in this area is mainly Regions (103826) and some country-specific checks (102592).

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3449400

  • To meet Costa Rica and El Salvador e-invoicing requirements (Province, District, Canton numeric hierarchy + text), you need a small custom solution (Custom Business Object + Custom Fields + BAdIs / logic) and then map those fields to the XML.

For example custom solution:

Use Custom Business Objects:

  1. In app Custom Business Objects:
    • Country (CR or SV)
    • ProvinceCode
    • CantonCode (numeric)
    • CantonName
    • DistrictCode (numeric)
    • DistrictName
    • UI-enabled
    • OData enabled
    • Create CBO Z_CR_SV_GEO (example).
    • Fields:
    • Mark it as:
  2. You now have a simple master data app where local users can maintain the official lists of provinceâ€“cantonâ€“district codes for CR and SV.

Add address fields to Business Partner

Use Custom Fields app:

  • Business Context

 

  • Create two numeric or text fields:
    • Z_CR_CANTON_CODE
    • Z_CR_DISTRICT_CODE
  • Mark them as:
    • Manage Business Partner
    • UI-relevant for:
    • OData-relevant so theyâ€™re visible for XML mapping.
  • Assign field with your CBO

 

  • Implement Badi, for example below:

 

Use the fields in the e-invoicing XML

  • If using SAP DRC with a custom/non-localized format:
    • Region (Province)
    • Z_CR_CANTON_CODE
    • Z_CR_DISTRICT_CODE
    • Use DRC enhancement points (Badi / mapping exits) to read the BP address:
    • Map them to the required XML elements

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Silent Login of Fiori/UI5 Application
entry.content:
Ok, for those who might suffer the same problem, here is the solution:

First, you need to disable authentication for C4C and html5 repo by setting the attribute authenticationType: "none".

This, on the other hand, will raise another issue of CSRF Token Validation Failed when you try to create/update record in your target system - C4C in my case. This can be fixed by introducing a fetch for a CSRF token in the following manner:

context is this that is passed to a helper method. The below is part of the helper method.

fetch(`/sap/c4c/odata/v1/c4codataapi/[Collection Name]`, {
                method: "GET",
                headers: {
                    Accept: "application/json",
                    "X-CSRF-Token": "Fetch"
                },
            }).then((response) => {
                context.getOwnerComponent()._token = response.headers.get("x-csrf-token");
            });

Once you have the token, do the following before record creation / update:

oModel.setHeaders({
                    "X-CSRF-Token": that.getOwnerComponent()._token
                });

Hope that can save someone sometime.

Br,
Aleks.

entry.title: Re: SAC Scripting : Measure Value
entry.content:
@shiva1233 

You did not mention reading measure value from Chart or Table. You can use getresultset to read the values.

https://help.sap.com/doc/1639cb9ccaa54b2592224df577abe822/release/en-US/index.html#DataSource_MgetResultSet

Check the return type of the API and refer to the formatted value.

You can also use Script Variable to store the measure values and then assign this to dynamic text.

// Get the result set from the chart's data source
var resultSet = Chart_1.getDataSource().getResultSet();

// Check if there are any results
if (resultSet.length > 0) {
    // Get the first result (e.g., if it's a single summary value)
    var firstDataPoint = resultSet[0];

    // Get the formatted value of the measure dimension
    var measureText = firstDataPoint["@MeasureDimension"].formattedValue;

    // Set the text widget to display the measure value
    Text_1.applyText(measureText);
} else {
    Text_1.applyText("No data available.");
}

 Hope this helps !

Nikhil
